text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.19.10, Receipt, Assignment, and Consideration of TEFRA Partnership Cases.
MATERIAL CHANGES

Added new IRM section, Program Scope and Objectives, and its related subsections to comply with the Deputy Commissioner of Services and Enforcement and Operations Support memo, dated September 14, 2016, entitled Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity and Understanding of Internal Controls.

Added new IRM section, Related Resources, information on the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR), based on guidance from the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) and Branch 3 of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration).

Revised IRM 8.19.10.5.1, Initial Case Procedures to incorporate Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0621-0019, Reissuance of Interim Guidance on Initial Conference Procedures for Liability, Penalty Appeals and Innocent Spouse Cases - 06/30/2021.

Updated references to Appeals TEFRA Team, Campus TEFRA Function (CTF), Partnership Control System (PCS) and TEFRA Coordinator to Appeals TEFRA/BBA Team, Campus Pass-through Function (CPF), Pass-through Control System (PCS) and Pass-through Coordinator throughout.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 8.19.10 dated April 19, 2016 is superseded. Incorporated Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0621- 0019, Reissuance of Interim Guidance on Initial Conference Procedures for Liability, Penalty Appeals and Innocent Spouse Cases – 06/30/2021.
All Appeals employees working with TEFRA partnership returns.
Director, Specialized Examination Programs and Referrals

Scope and (
) Purpose: This IRM section describes the statute processes and procedures working TEFRA Key and Partner Cases in the IRS Independent Office of Appeals (Appeals). (
) Audience: Appeals Technical Employees and Appeals Team Managers that work TEFRA cases (
) Policy Owner: Appeals Technical Guidance is under the Director, Specialized Examination Programs and Referrals (
) Program Owner: Appeals Technical Guidance is the program office responsible for providing technical and Procedural Guidance to Appeals employees for TEFRA issues. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established procedures on HOW TO CONTACT AN ANALYST. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information Page for this IRM. (
) TEFRA was passed in
to allow examinations and statutes to be con- trolled at the partnership level. This eliminated the need to control each individual partner statute. (
) Section
of the Bipartisan Budget Act (BBA) of
repealed TEFRA nership and Electing Large Partnership (ELP) provisions beginning with tax years beginning

and replaced it with a new centralized partnership audit regime. The new regime provides for determination, assessment and lection of underpayments at the partnership level unless certain elections made by the partnership. (
) TEFRA policy was established in response to the partnership provisions of Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of
Responsibilities (
) The author of this IRM is shown on the Product Catalog Page as the origina- tor. Reports (
) Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PPQA) provides trend and data analyses and detailed summary reports for Appeals. and Acronyms (
) See IRM
, Common Terms Used in Appeals, for common terms and deﬁnitions used in IRM Part
Terms listed in this exhibit are not included this section. Resources (
) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see https://www. irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights
page
A (
) Internal Revenue Manual
TEFRA policy was established in response to the partnership provisions of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of 1982.

) All guidance in this section of the IRM concerning the Campus Pass-through Functions (CPFs) is for cases controlled on the Pass-Through Control System (PCS). The CPFs only work with key cases and partners controlled by PCS. references in this IRM to appeals officers (AO) applies equally to appeals case leaders and any actions required by appeals team managers (ATM) performed by appeals team case leaders as to their own cases.
) TEFRA BBA (ATT) (

) Appeals employees must follow the work request procedures to request ATT assistance. Use of the ATT is mandatory for agreement package, closing package, and FPAA preparation. Follow the work request procedures in IRM
, Appeals TEFRA BBA Team (ATT). Also see detailed procedures using the ATT on their Appeals TEFRA Shar
oint site. A link to the site is found on the Appeals TEFRA & Bipartisan Budget Act (BBA) of
website.
) Receiving and Closing Partnerships (
) IRS source functions that send TEFRA partnership cases to Appeals should follow the Appeals Case Routing page listed on SERP. (
) Route Closed TEFRA cases to APS as directed (via the direct shipment table) when ACAP is entered.
) Guidance for Account Processing Support (
) This subsection provides procedures on the receipt of TEFRA partnership cases by APS and other Appeals employees responsible for processing (
) This subsection supplements the general information contained in IRM
, Appeals Case Processing Manual. It contains information on TEFRA partner- ship cases only. Information on partner cases is contained in IRM
information on Administrative Adjustment Requests (AARs) is contained in

) The duties of APS will generally be standardized. However, because job and duties vary from office to office in the processing areas, these instructions generally will not specify the title of the person responsible for the task. Local office staffing may dictate who will process various documents.
) Receiving Case Files (
) The partnership case can be either a non-docketed or docketed case. The return will be ﬁled on a Form
) All TEFRA partnership cases should be transmitted to Appeals on Form APS will promptly sign and date stamp the Form
and return a copy to originator. (
) Each TEFRA partnership case should be clearly marked as a TEFRA case Compliance. The partnership case ﬁle should be ﬂagged with Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Case Processing. In the block titled “Forward to Technical Services”, the box for TEFRA or Non-TEFRA Key should be checked. (

) If the case was noted as a TEFRA key case, it is mandatory that the case controlled on the Pass-Through Control System (PCS). APS should secure current AMDISA as well as TSUMYP and TSINQP prints and include them the case ﬁle (the PICF code should be
). Refer to IRM
for information the PCS.

) The administrative ﬁle should contain the same items shown in IRM
(except a protest). In addition, the following information should included: a. A copy of the FPAA b. A copy of the certiﬁed mailing list c. A copy of the Tax Court petition or petitions (
) The processing procedures discussed in IRM
(other than verifying the statute of limitations date) also apply to docketed cases. In addition, after establishing the controls as stated in IRM
, forward the case ﬁle to Associate Area Counsel for answer. (

) If multiple petitions have been ﬁled, advise Associate Area Counsel at the the case is sent for answer so that the appropriate action can be taken. Until Associate Area Counsel advises which petition is controlling, control each docket number on ACDS as a separate partnership case workunit. (

) When Appeals is notiﬁed of the controlling docket number, all other related docket numbers will be dismissed. Upon receipt of the TLCATS Transmittal with dismissal information, APS updates ACDS as follows: • ACTION CODE: “ORDENT” • TODATE: The order entered date as indicated on the TLCATS transmit- tal (
) When copies of the dismissals are received, APS closes the dismissed docketed cases on ACDS as follows: a. CLOSING CODE
if dismissed, Compliance ﬁeld office or Campus issued FPAA and Appeals hours expended. b. CLOSING CODE
if dismissed, Appeals issued FPAA. c. CLOSING CODE

if dismissed, Compliance ﬁeld office or Campus issued FPAA and no Appeals hours expended. d. CLOSING DATE: Date closed. e. ACTION CODE: ACKCLS. f. TODATE AND FROMDATE: Date closed. g. NOTES: “Dismissed--multiple petitions ﬁled, controlling DKT#XXXX-XX.” (
) Place copies of the dismissals in the TEFRA partnership administrative ﬁle. (

) If the case was controlled on the Pass-Through Control System (PCS), APS notiﬁes the key case CPF that the TEFRA key case is docketed. Note: Instructions for determining which CPF is the key case CPF may be found
The administrative ﬁle should contain the same items shown in IRM 8.19.10.3.2 (except a protest). In addition, the following information should be
Place copies of the dismissals in the TEFRA partnership administrative ﬁle.

) APS instructs the CPF to mark their key case ﬁle to show the docket number and to insert a statement that no agreement forms should be executed without contacting the AO ﬁrst. (
) APS instructs the CPF to add the docket number to the PCS database. (
) The key case CPF should be notiﬁed with this information using secure email. Centralized System Processing (

Reminder: A TEFRA partnership case should not be accepted in Appeals unless there are at least 365 days remaining on the statute.
The case level information speciﬁc to non-docketed TEFRA cases that must be input on ACDS is as follows:
a. TYPE: TEFRA for a TEFRA partnership case. b. MFT:
for Form

c. FEATURE CODE: Enter appropriate code, when applicable. The most common codes are: TS for Tax Shelter. A TEFRA case is not automati- cally a tax shelter. CE for CIC (Coordinated Industry Cases). d. KEY T/P: Always blank on TEFRA partnership case. e. KEY TIN: Always blank on TEFRA partnership case. f. SNTYPE: Enter one of the following codes as applicable:
STATUTE CODE: Must have an entry if the statute date is blank.
• Revised $ (Def-O/A) - refer to Exhibit
; this is not entered the case is closed from ACDS d. PENALTY: • Proposed $ (Def-O/A) - leave blank • Revised $ (Def-O/A) - leave blank Limitations (
) For information on APS responsibility for statutes, including processing a consent, refer to IRM
) For additional responsibilities for TEFRA partnership cases, refer to IRM
Files (
) Effective May
, APS will no longer create and maintain office ﬁles. (

) After a case has been closed in Appeals and if information is needed from administrative ﬁle, the AO must request the ﬁle by completing the ACDS Update Request Form found in APGolf. The completed form should be sent the following mailbox for processing: *AP-TS-APS Closed Case Doc Request. Control (
) The PCS is a separate database with TEFRA and non-TEFRA pass-thru and investor information that interfaces with Master File and AIMS. (

) The PCS does the following: a. Contains pass-thru entity and related investor records. b. Establishes a linkage relationship between pass-thru entity (key case) records and related investor records. c. Distinguishes between TEFRA and non-TEFRA cases using numeric codes. Generally, non-TEFRA investor cases have even numbers and TEFRA partner cases have odd numbers (PICF Codes). d. Places a freeze condition on the corresponding AIMS record of investors. This prevents premature closure of the AIMS record. e. Generates various reports for the purpose of maintaining the data base and processing pending statute cases. f. Generates investor settlement letters. g. Generates notices to TEFRA partners. h. Provides IDRS terminal research capabilities for investor and key case records. i. Provides reports for CPF’s TEFRA and non-TEFRA inventory and man- agement information. j. Identiﬁes TEFRA cases with penalty issues. (
) PCS does not replace AIMS, but PCS supplements AIMS by providing addi- tional information. Appeals assessments are made by closing the case ﬁle through AIMS using Form
) Refer to IRM
, Pass-Through Control System (PCS) Handbook for addi- tional information on the PCS.
Appeals Pass-Through Entity Handbook

The PCS is a separate database with TEFRA and non-TEFRA pass-thru entity and investor information that interfaces with Master File and AIMS.

The PCS is a separate database with TEFRA and non-TEFRA pass-thru entity and investor information that interfaces with Master File and AIMS. The PCS does the following: a. Contains pass-thru entity and related investor records. b. Establishes a linkage relationship between pass-thru entity (key case) records and related investor records. c. Distinguishes between TEFRA and non-TEFRA cases using numeric codes. Generally, non-TEFRA investor cases have even numbers and TEFRA partner cases have odd numbers (PICF Codes). d. Places a freeze condition on the corresponding AIMS record of investors. This prevents premature closure of the AIMS record. e. Generates various reports for the purpose of maintaining the data base and processing pending statute cases. f. Generates investor settlement letters. g. Generates notices to TEFRA partners. h. Provides IDRS terminal research capabilities for investor and key case records. i. Provides reports for CPF’s TEFRA and non-TEFRA inventory and man- agement information. j. Identiﬁes TEFRA cases with penalty issues. PCS does not replace AIMS, but PCS supplements AIMS by providing addi- tional information. Appeals assessments are made by closing the case ﬁle through AIMS using Form
Refer to IRM
, Pass-Through Control System (PCS) Handbook for addi- tional information on the PCS.
Receipt, Assignment, and Consideration of TEFRA Partnership Cases 8.19.10 page 7

) Records established on AIMS by PCS receive the same processing as any other record established on AIMS. a. If the information provided to Master File is incomplete or inaccurate, record is rejected and AIMS will not be established. b. If the record already exists on AIMS, the PCS request does not alter information on the existing AIMS record except to update the Partnership Investor Control File (PICF) indicator on the AIMS record. (
) A record may be established on PCS as a key case record whether or not it linked to an investor. (

) A record established on PCS as an investor record must be linked to a key case. If all linkages to a previously established investor record are closed or deleted from PCS, the investor record will drop from PCS. (
) A PCS record is considered a tier if it is linked to a key case and itself has investors. A tier is identiﬁed by the # sign on a TSUMY. (
) A closed key case record is retained on the system as long as at least one investor record is linked to it. (
) If the PCS data base has records on both a partner and a key case, an inquiry for both records is necessary to obtain complete information. (

) To secure full research on a tiered partnership, it is necessary to make two PCS inquiries. You must request both of the following: a. A TSUMYI to secure information on the partnership which is the control- ling key case. b. A TSUMYP to secure information on the partners in the tier. (
) Command Code (CC) TSUMY gives a display of linkage information. a. TSUMY “I” will list all key cases a partner is linked to. b. TSUMY “P” will list all partners linked to a speciﬁc key case. (
) The AIMS PICF code displayed on the AMDIS or AMDISA inquiry request can determine whether a return is on PCS. a. PICF codes of
through
indicate the record appears on PCS. A PICF code of
indicates the record does not appear on PCS. b. PICF codes are displayed and deﬁned in IRM
This infor- mation is also located in Document
(ADP and IDRS Information). (
) Command Code TSINQI can provide information about a partner and a speciﬁc partnership linkage. (

) Command Code TSINQP provides detailed key case information only. The CPF code which indicates the key case CPF is on the TSINQP. For information on identifying the key case CPF, refer to the Appeals TEFRA & Bipartisan get Act (BBA) of
website . Assignment, and Consideration of TEFRA Partnership page (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Records established on AIMS by PCS receive the same processing as any other record established on AIMS.
A PCS record is considered a tier if it is linked to a key case and itself has investors. A tier is identiﬁed by the # sign on a TSUMY.
(1) If the PCS data base has records on both a partner and a key case, an inquiry for both records is necessary to obtain complete information.

) The one-year statute date will be entered as follows: TSCHG
- MMDDYYYYA, where A is the Investor Closing Code. (
) The
-Day Date is the date that is

days after the Notice of Beginning Administrative Proceeding (NBAP) is issued to the last notice partner. It signiﬁes the earliest date that a FPAA can be issued to the Tax Matters (TMP) without triggering an “untimely notice to a partner” problem. See IRM
) The key case CPF manually inputs the
-Day Date to the key case record by CC TSCHG using Form
) The
-Day Date may be researched by using CC TSINQP. (
) The
-Day Date is the date that the FPAA was mailed to the TMP. The for the notice partners must be mailed within
days of mailing the FPAA the TMP. (
) If the FPAA is not mailed to a notice partner by the

th day after the FPAA was mailed to the TMP, and the TEFRA proceedings are still ongoing at the time he/she receives notice, the partner may elect to have the partnership items treated as nonpartnership items under IRC
See IRM
) If the FPAA is not mailed to a notice partner by the

th day after the FPAA was mailed to the TMP, and the proceeding has already been completed, partnership items will automatically convert to nonpartnership items unless partner elects to apply the FPAA, a court decision, or settlement agreement. See IRM
) The
-Day Date may be researched using CC TSUMYP and CC TSINQP. (

) The PCS record indicators are displayed to assist the user in obtaining infor- mation on the account for processing purposes. (
) Some of the record indicators are as follows: •

• Penalty/Affected Item Report Indicator • TEFRA Penalty/Affected Item Code (
) For more information on these items, refer to IRM
, PCS Database Elements. (
) The
indicator shows that a full record has not been established on AIMS. When the

indicator appears on the PCS record, only the following will displayed on the PCS record: • AIMS status code • Special project code • Name control • Source code • Employee group code • TIN • MFT • Tax period • Primary business code (PBC) • Activity code (
) The AIMS name and statute date for the account will not appear on the PCS until the record is fully established on AIMS. Investor (PICF) (
) The PICF indicator prevents an AIMS account from closing until all linkage record freezes are released using CC TSCLS. (
) The PICF indicator is automatically set on the AIMS record by establishing record on PCS. (
) The PICF indicator appears on an AMDIS or AMDISA display by the literal PICF Code X on page
) PICF indicator codes and conditions are as follows: •
= no partnership investor control ﬁle data. •
= Linked TEFRA key case. •
= Linked non-TEFRA key case. •
= Electing large partnership key case. •
= Investor with both open TEFRA linkage and open non-TEFRA linkage •
= Investor with at least one open TEFRA key case linkage. •
= Investor with at least one open non-TEFRA key case linkage but TEFRA key case linkage. •
= Investor with no open linkages and at least one closed TEFRA case linkage. •
= Investor with no open linkages and at least one closed non-TEFRA key case linkage, but no closed TEFRA key case linkage. (
) The TEFRA indicator identiﬁes key case, tier, and other investor records as TEFRA or non-TEFRA.

) Form
is used to update a one-year statute date on PCS (either to a date or to reﬂect that an assessment has been made). Form

may also be used to update a one-year statute date on PCS, but only to a date. Instructions for both forms are on the back of the respective forms and are also available on the Appeals TEFRA & Bipartisan Budget Act (BBA) of
website .
) Guidance for Appeals Officers (AO) (

) This subsection is intended to give AO’s speciﬁc guidance in working TEFRA partnership cases. Since the provisions of TEFRA require different technical and procedural treatment from those used for non-TEFRA cases, the AO should be familiar with the entire contents of IRM
Caution: Users are cautioned to seek guidance from the Appeals TEFRA Technical Specialists if questions of authority arise. (

) The Appeals Office will have jurisdiction of the partnership case. When it is completed, they will close it to Laguna Niguel APS. The key case CPF will take the necessary actions to notify the partner CPF to close the partner returns when the proceeding is completed, including issuing closing letters based on the instructions provided by Appeals.
) Initial Case Procedures (
) Within
days of receipt of a newly assigned or transferred case: • Complete statute veriﬁcation Note: For TEFRA key cases, this guidance shall extend the statute veriﬁcation time frame provided in IRM
, Appeals Technical Employees (ATE) Statute Responsibility for TEFRA Key Cases, to

The TMP executes statute extensions on behalf of the partners of the TEFRA partnership. An error in the determination of the correct TMP may result in barred deﬁciencies. If it is determined that the TMP designated by the partnership did not qualify to be the TMP (especially if the TMP signed statute extensions), consideration should be given to returning the case as a premature referral.

) For non-docketed cases, if the key case was not linked on PCS, it is recom- mended that the case be returned to the examiner as a premature referral. Several problems could arise if the case is not linked on PCS: a. The CPF would not be involved and the NBAPs may not have been mailed to the TMP and all notice partners; this could create an untimely notice issue later on (see IRM
). b. The CPF would not be able to mail settlement letters or FPAAs---Appeals would have to mail all of these. c. The one-year statute dates of the partners could not be tracked on PCS. (
) For docketed cases, if the key case was not linked on PCS, prepare and send Form

(PCS Establish or Add Without Notice Generation) to the PCS Co- ordinator at the key case CPF. The transmittal should clearly inform the CPF that the linkage is being requested on a TEFRA partnership. NBAPs should be sent to the partners. The Compliance function may agree to perform the linking procedure for Appeals. (

) The TMP should be invited to attend the conference whether or not he/she ﬁled the protest. (

) Any unagreed partner has the right to attend the conference. However, in to attend, they must notify the TMP that they wish to attend. This right also applies in docketed cases where the TMP or any unagreed partner ﬁled a petition. Holding (
) For non-docketed cases, schedule the conference with the TMP. Send a con- ference letter to the TMP regardless of who ﬁled the protest. Letter
should be used when scheduling the conference with the TMP. If a partner other than or in addition to the TMP ﬁled a protest, a standard Letter
should be sent to the partner. (
) For docketed cases, schedule the conference with the counsel of record by using Letter
) The TMP is required to notify all partners, notice or non-notice, of the scheduled conference. (
) Appeals and the TMP will determine the time and place for all conferences. Arrangements will generally not be changed merely for the convenience of another partner. (

) If the conference requires space to accommodate a large group of participants, the AO should inquire if adequate government facilities are available. However, if it is necessary to rent conference space, the TMP should make the arrange- ments and be responsible for the cost. Affected (
) Partner level elements of penalties and affected item issues should be consid- ered with the partnership case. (

) Review the examiner’s affected item report and determine a recommended settlement position on the partner level elements of penalties or affected based upon the activities at the partnership level. This will include the over- valuation of assets. (

) Prepare an abbreviated affected item appeals case memo (ACM) for the rec- ommended settlement position. A copy of the abbreviated affected item ACM will be included with the closing package to the key case CPF. See Exhibit
for a sample affected item ACM. (

) Generally, any additional facts which are based on activities at the partner level will only be considered in evaluating a partner’s individual case after partnership proceeding has been completed (but see (
) below): a. For partnership tax years ending after August

, penalties are termined at the partnership level. Any penalties determined will be assessed and the partner must ﬁle a refund claim after the penalties assessed and paid, at which time additional facts unique to that partner (including partner reasonable cause and good faith defenses to a penalty) may be presented. may be presented. (
) For partnership tax years ending after August

, if the number of partners is relatively small (generally ﬁve or fewer), you may consider partner level defenses to a penalty as part of the consideration of the partnership case. If a settlement is reached, Form
-LT(AD) will be used. On the Schedule of Adjustments page of the Form
–LT(AD), partnership level penalties (including percentages) will be shown in Part I and partner level defenses to these penalties (including percentages) will be shown in Part II. Exhibit
is an example of a Form
-LT(AD) Schedule of Adjustments page with penalties.

Caution: It is very important that any reduction of a partnership level penalty after considering a partner level defense be shown in Part II. Partner level defenses are not partnership items and are therefore not subject to a request for consistent settlement. If a partner level penalty is shown in Part I, it would be subject to a request for consistent settlement by any other partners (including those that did not establish reasonable cause, such as a promoter). (
) For partnership tax years ending after August

, if the penalty is unagreed when the partnership proceeding concludes, Appeals will issue a Notice of Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment (FPAA) to address the penalty at the partnership level. a. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partnership level defenses must contest them as a part of the partnership proceeding. b. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partner level defenses, such as good faith and reasonable cause, must contest the penalties by ﬁling a refund claim after the penalties are assessed and paid. See IRC

penalty for promoting an abusive tax shelter was asserted, contact the examiner to advise of the proposed partner- ship case penalty settlement, particularly if the proposal is a full concession the Government. (
) When evaluating the settlement position for a case, consider the effect any offer may have on all partners in view of their right to consistent settlement. (
) In addition, be mindful of procedural problems that certain settlement offers may cause for the CPFs in processing the case.

) IRC
) allows partners to enter into a settlement agreement to ﬁx the correct treatment of partnership items with ﬁnality. IRC
) gives other partners the right to request a settlement consistent with another partner’s settlement of partnership items. (
) The request for consistent settlement must be made by the later of:
days after an FPAA was mailed to the TMP;
days after the settlement agreement was accepted for the Commis- sioner; or
days after an untimely FPAA is mailed to the partner. (
) The partner must request the consistent settlement in writing and identify the speciﬁc settlement for which he/she is requesting consistent settlement. (
) The consistent settlement will be processed on Form
-PT(AD) and identi- ﬁed as “Consistent Settlement.” Appeals personnel should write the term “Consistent Settlement” on the top of the agreement form. See IRM
For docketed cases, also follow the procedures in IRM
page
Caution: If the agreement is not identiﬁed as a “Consistent Settlement” another partner may claim the agreement starts a second 60-day period for re- questing consistent settlement.

) Consider any effect the settlement will have on the ability of the CPF to process the partner returns. When a settlement has been formulated in a project case, the key case CPF should be provided the terms of the settlement and pro forma copies of the documents that they will be required to process. (
) If a closing agreement (Form
) is required, Appeals is responsible for preparing all closing agreements and securing them from the partners. Refer IRM
for information when using closing agreements in docketed cases. (
) If partial agreements are required, Appeals is responsible for preparing all partial agreements and securing the agreements from all partners. Refer to IRM
for more information on partial agreements. (
) If the case is not linked on PCS, the CPF cannot be used to mail any agreement forms or FPAAs to the partners. (

) Avoid settlements based upon a net cash investment unless the examiner already substantiated the amount of each partner’s cash investment. The key case CPF will not have the means to verify cash investments. Cash out-of- pocket settlements based on a partner’s cash investment are generally not compatible with the concept of a uniﬁed proceeding because of the veriﬁcation problem. (
) If a partner’s cash contribution percentage does not equal his/her proﬁt and loss percentage, a cash out-of-pocket settlement may also create consistency problems. (
) Avoid this problem by offering all partners their pro-rata share of a speciﬁc dollar amount for settlement purposes.
If a partner’s cash contribution percentage does not equal his/her proﬁt and loss percentage, a cash out-of-pocket settlement may also create consistency

to alert the key case CPF to return the agreement forms to you without executing them. Include envelopes to ensure that the CPF returns the agreement forms to you. These packages are sent electronically. (

) The determination of a partner’s adjusted basis in the partnership which is not properly determinable at the partnership level is an affected item. The correct treatment of an affected item must be determined after the partnership pro- ceeding is concluded. See IRM
for a discussion of adjusted basis as an affected item. (
) When changes are made at the partnership level which affect basis, clearly explain the change in the Form
and in the remarks section of the Form
-A. Each partners’ basis should be shown on the Form
-Z. These packages are sent electronically. (

) Where there are many direct and indirect partners in a TEFRA partnership, it may be beneﬁcial for both the IRS and the partnership to process the case having the partnership pay the assessment instead of distributing the adjust- ments to all partners. (

) This type of a settlement would be particularly useful in large promotions when the CPF is either holding hundreds of partners in suspense or has decided to not link one or more indirect partners because there are hundreds of partners that would have to be linked to that partner. Allocating adjustments to hundreds of indirect partners requires substantial resources by the CPF and the dilution of the adjustments after the allocation may ultimately result in little or no tax owed by these partners. (
) This type of settlement would also often be beneﬁcial to the partnership as it would not have to amend hundreds of Schedule K-
s for subsequent tax years if the settlement would have resulted in additional deductions in those years. (
) The details of a partnership level settlement are explained in a Form
, Closing Agreement on Final Determination Covering Speciﬁc Matters.
Caution: Disclose a partner’s partner level item adjustments only to the speciﬁc partner.

Receipt, Assignment, and Consideration of TEFRA Partnership Cases 8.19.10 page 21
Generally, a partnership level agreement can only be secured when the adjust- ments passing through to all underlying partners will result in a deﬁciency. (
) The highest level effective tax rate should be used when calculating the amount of tax owed. The partnership must also pay all additions to tax including interest and penalties. (
) The payment made by the partnership is considered a distribution to the partners in the year paid or the year when the payment became ﬁxed and terminable. (
) The impact of the payment as a distribution to the partners should be included in the Form
settlement agreement. (

) The payment made by the partnership will impact the basis of partners. The partners’ capital accounts and basis should be increased by the amount of income that should have been reported, and then reduced by their share of tax paid by the partnership. That share is treated as a distribution in the year paid and will generate additional tax to the extent it exceeds the partner’s outside basis or increases income (by reducing basis) on the sale of the part- nership interest. (
) If this type of a settlement is being contemplated, the AO should contact the Appeals TEFRA Technical Specialists for additional information. (
) An entity that is treated as a partnership for U.S. tax purposes and has a foreign partner could be required to withhold tax under the following withhold- ing tax authorities: • IRC
and IRC
, U.S. source Fixed Determinable Annual Peri- odical (FDAP) income, and • IRC
, Effectively Connected Taxable Income (ECTI) (
) The withholding tax under IRC
and IRC
requires: a. A domestic partnership to withhold tax on a foreign partner’s allocable share of U.S. source FDAP income. b. Additionally, IRC
and IRC
require withholding any time a nership makes a payment of U.S. source FDAP income to a nonresident alien regardless of whether this person is a partner in the partnership making the payment. (
) The withholding tax under IRC
requires any partnership engaged in a trade or business within the U.S. to withhold tax on a foreign partner’s allocable share of ECTI. (
) Partnerships should also be aware of possible withholding obligations under IRC
(regarding ECTI allocable to IRC
(c) foreign tax exempt organi- zations and gross investment income of a private foundation) and IRC
(regarding the disposition of U.S. real property interest by a foreign partner- ship). page
Generally, a partnership level agreement can only be secured when the adjust- ments passing through to all underlying partners will result in a deﬁciency.

) When no changes are recommended to the partnership return, either obtain agreement forms showing no change from all notice partners remaining in the proceeding, issue a no-change FPAA, or issue a No Adjustments Letter. (
) Generally if the CPF is not able to use the Form
and Schedule K-
s for no-change case, the case is not a true no change. In this situation, follow the procedures for cases with changes. (
) Procedures for securing agreement forms are the same for agreed cases and no-change cases and are found in IRM

) The no-change FPAA or no-change agreement form gives notice of the completion of the administrative proceeding to all notice partners still participat- ing in the proceedings, allows the Service to assess inconsistent ﬁling partners, and to issue a notice of deﬁciency on the affected items requiring partner level determinations. This will also prevent any partner from later ﬁling an Administrative Adjustment Request with respect to the partnership items. (
) The No Adjustments Letter provides a streamlined procedure for use on true no-change cases. -

An Administrative Adjustment Request (AAR) has not been ﬁled by either the TMP or any partner. The TMP has indicated agreement with the no change. No partner (whose partnership items have not converted) ﬁled inconsis

) Be careful to use the no-change procedure only if no partnership level item changed and the TMP has agreed to the no-change determination. Some terminations may appear to be a no-change but are not. Changes to partnership level components of basis, at risk and passive losses are not no- change situations. See paragraphs (
) and (
) below for details. (

) Changes to partnership level components of basis are not no-change situa- tions. Some partnership level components for basis are the amounts of: a. the initial capital contributions to the partnership; b. all subsequent capital contributions to the partnership; c. distributions from the partnership; d. partner’s share of taxable income, nontaxable income, losses, and de- ductions; e. partner’s share of partnership liabilities; and f. optional adjustments to the basis of partnership property pursuant to an IRC
election. (

) Changes to partnership level components of at risk are not no-change situa- tions. Some partnership level components of at risk are: a. Whether the loans or notes are recourse, nonrecourse, or contingent. b. Whether the partner is a limited or a general partner. c. Whether the lender has an interest other than as a creditor. (

) Changes to partnership level components of passive activity losses are not no-change situations. Some partnership level components of passive activity losses are: a. Whether the partnership was engaged in a rental activity. b. Whether the partnership was engaged in a trade or business for purposes of IRC
c. Whether a partner should be treated as a limited partner. d. Whether income is portfolio income. (
) In addition to paragraphs (
) and (

) above, the following should also receive a no-change settlement agreement or a no-change FPAA: a. Changing the character of partnership level items even if there are no changes in the amount shown on the return. b. Any other change to a partnership item determination which changes affected items at the partner level. c. Any change to allocation percentages.
Changes to partnership level components of basis are not no-change situa- tions. Some partnership level components for basis are the amounts of:

the initial capital contributions to the partnership; all subsequent capital contributions to the partnership; distributions from the partnership; partner’s share of taxable income, nontaxable income, losses, and de- ductions; partner’s share of partnership liabilities; and optional adjustments to the basis of partnership property pursuant to an IRC
election.
Changes to partnership level components of at risk are not no-change situa- tions. Some partnership level components of at risk are:
Changes to partnership level components of passive activity losses are not no-change situations. Some partnership level components of passive activity
In addition to paragraphs (2), (3) and (4) above, the following should also not receive a no-change settlement agreement or a no-change FPAA:

Changing the character of partnership level items even if there are no changes in the amount shown on the return. Any other change to a partnership item determination which changes affected items at the partner level. Any change to allocation percentages.

) After the Form
, ACM, Schedule of Adjustments page, and agreement forms (if Appeals will be mailing them to the partners) are prepared, submit case to your ATM for review and approval. (

) All settlements must be reviewed and approved by the manager before agreement forms are mailed to the TMP or to the partners. This is especially important because of the consistent settlement provisions of the uniﬁed ceedings. If just one partner agreement is erroneously executed, the Service may be bound to the same settlement for all unagreed partners.
